name: NAD+
overview: NAD+ (Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide) is a coenzyme found in all living cells, not technically a peptide. It plays a crucial role in cellular energy production, DNA repair, and numerous metabolic processes. NAD+ levels naturally decline with age.
side_effects_common: cramping or discomfort during IV infusion
who_should_avoid: known hypersensitivity to niacin or NAD+ compounds
interactions_notes: May interact with medications affecting liver metabolism. Can interact with blood pressure medications. May affect glucose metabolism - caution with diabetes medications. Discuss all supplements and medications with clinician.
dosing_ranges_literature: Oral NAD+ precursors (NMN, NR) typically use 250-1000 mg daily. Injectable NAD+ protocols vary widely from 25-100 mg subcutaneous to 250-1000 mg IV infusions. IV infusions are typically administered slowly over 2-4 hours to minimize side effects.
storage_notes: Store unreconstituted NAD+ powder refrigerated at 2-8Â°C, protected from light. After reconstitution with sterile saline or sterile water, use immediately or store refrigerated for up to 24 hours. IV formulations may have different requirements.
